newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai soybean ends mixed on regulation.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai soybean ends mixed on regulation.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended mixed on Wednesday, with institutions liquidating large amounts of positions in the November contract because of new regulations covering futures markets, traders said.

The China Securities newspaper said on Wednesday that China's top securities watchdog has ordered commodity futures exchanges to abolish a settlement system that sets limits on the total amount for physical delivery.
Traders said the news made institutions liquidate their positions.
"Some institutions were afraid that their illegal trading in the futures market will be exposed by the new regulations," one trader said.

The key November 1996 contract ended at 3,318 yuan ($399) per tonne, rising seven yuan. It opened at 3,320 yuan, hitting an intra-day high of 3,340 and a low of 3,300. Open interest fell to 25,840 lots from 38,840. One lot is five tonnes.
January fell 10 to 3,210 yuan per tonne, March two to 3,210, May did not trade, July was unchanged at 3,320 and September rose five to 3,350. ($1=8.3005 yuan)
